Oracle is a results oriented organization so quarterly pressures are standard. If you are looking for potluck lunches try another company. Larry is a strong believer in multiple sales reps calling on the same customer. This can cause challenges with customers and sometimes creates tension internally.
advice: We should strongly consider streamlining some of our internal processes and internal systems. The acquisition strategy is working... continue to aggressively invest where it makes sense.
pros: Working at Oracle offers a wealth of benefits... Here are a few to consider: First, you will benefit by having a top-tier software company, like Oracle, on your resume. Second, successful sales reps are compensated handsomely for their success. Third, the level of intelligence and experience of many of your coworkers and extended teams will be extremely high. And last, you will have good access to the executive level…  at many companies.

cons: Demanding at times, low perks.
advice: Keep up the good work.
pros: Great company to work for.

Some thing or the other will change and you'll have to accommodate for it.- schedules are very aggressive but in my opinion not realistic. To give an example, product hasn't shipped 18 months after a previously advertised "code freeze" date.- you work a lot but get a sense of not having achieved as much.- if you like to code a lot, then this isn't the place :(- nobody makes firm commitments on requirements/schedules - I guess it is a way to make sure anything you don't know now can be made a "requirement" later.

advice: Dont skimp on training for employees.
pros: Lot of technologies to play around with. Good people to work with.
summary: Nice to place to grow. Put in a few years and move on.

cons: - One should always join the current firefight - Oracle has plenty - if one needs management attention. Sound workers should have made the choice to stay on without being noticed or appreciated.- Technology focused, management sees no value of professional degrees, like MBAs, MS etc., once you start working at Oracle. Though most manager will support the partial time-off required to do part-time studies.- Ora… cle does not tap into excellent social networks its employees are exposed to. (this choice is partly due to stricter security standards)- There are plenty of re-orgs and it can get pretty turbulent in some groups due to various acquisitions in past and possibly in future. So, if one is joining now, stay adaptive and embrace the change. You may see multiple managers in coming years.
advice: - Value your 80% bottom workers, not just top 20%. They are keeping the bottom line cost under control and giving predictable output.- When you distribute award to most visible person who manages to fight off escalation, also give award to a person who keeps things under control.- Create more employee harmony and team events. Due to limited opportunity of growth, there is a lot of internal politics and back-b… iting among mid managers or among people who are management hopefuls.- Due to acquisition based innovation the drive to write white-papers, doing something cool, experimenting is going away. Bring it back. When we are done buying everybody possible, it will be time to find internal ability to innovate.
pros: - Software powerhouse, opportunity to work with various technologies- Stability, global diversification- Focus towards product and customers- Great sales team- Good employee benefits- Work-life balance (good company to raise family with)- Management is usually supportive of lateral transitions within the groups (e.g. from Manager to individual contributor and vice-versa)- Good gym- Has…  potential for growth
summary: Demonstrate, adapt, make right friends and be happy.

cons: HR policies and practices are very dark and secretive...although benefits are solid, salary, bonuses and promotions are not handled properly leaving some disgruntled employees. Those that do not understand how to manage their own careers are often left in the dust as mentor programs are lacking. As with most large corporations, being outside of HQ makes it difficult to really climb the corporate ladder. Communication…  is sporadic with some real gaps as employees are often left in the dark on key initiatives decreasing morale and lack of respect for senior leadership. However, I would have little to complain about if the HR and compensation practices improved.
advice: Show you value employees through your actions.
pros: Oracle provides solid benefits. The work schedule is flexible but can be demanding as we work in a global community. They are also very good about allowing employees to work from home or remote locations which is at the top of my list of perks. We have the ability to work with cutting edge technologies and have the resources and economies of scale that come along with working for such a large corporation. There are s… o many career opportunities available at Oracle that your options are endless. Overall, Oracle provides a good working environment, flexible work schedules, and an exciting product and service offering that won't have you snoring.
summary: Good working environment, flexible work schedules, and an exciting product/service offering that won't have you snoring.

cons: They beat the crap out of you. Extremely stressful. The travel is a killer and you cannot get of them. Favoritism and nepotism are rampant. Kissing up the right rear will take you places.
advice: Better life work balance and raises/promos should be made more equitable
pros: Challenging and access to all the software and insider tools.
summary: Great place to work if you can take it

cons: Big company. Great place to work... but if economy turns downward, employees suddenly feel like a number, and worry about layoffs, regardless of their previous contributions or longevity.
advice: Keep employee motivation toward the top of the priority list!
pros: Oracle is an exciting place to work. Things are constantly changing. Oracle is growing rapidly through acquisitions. This can sometimes be challenging. But it's also been very exciting as all these new employees are brought into the fold. For the most part, it's been an easy integration. And it's gratifying to hear from these people how much they like the Oracle culture and how impressed they are with the quality of … its employees.
summary: Big Company and Great Employer

cons: Not very innovative. It can be hard to change the direction of projects and many middleware projects seem doomed to fail or has very little potential for impact. Currently Oracle is hard to beat because it has many existing clients who are too lazy to switch to other products but eventually people will switch to superior products. You cannot simply fight SAP with aggressive salespeople. Too much acquisition can cause…  indigestion. There are many clients frustrated by the lack of integration between Oracle's products.
advice: Don't be too complacent.
pros: Established company with a lot of stability, good employee benefits. Oracle is a dominant player in its core areas despite threats from SAP and growing MySQL threat.
summary: Large, stable corporation not known for innovation

cons: It's not warm and fuzzy, it's competitive. It runs through cycles of collecting too many management layers looking for something to do (but cleans house by reorganizing annually to help shake them out). There is pressure to travel frequently and there are limited alternatives to excessive travel. It is often a place to learn Oracle technologies well, pay your dues, and depending on available assignments, just move on… .
advice: As far as I'm concerned, Oracle is on the right track.
pros: Oracle consistently pushes to keep consultants trained in the latest technology, and provides opportunities to exercise those technologies. Oracle allows consultants to take risks in order to succeed (or fail) based primarily on the individual's own performance. Oracle has no problem booting poor performers out the door. It keeps one pushing to stay on the edge. Benefits and salaries are better than average for the r… egion. A good long-term assignment can make Oracle employment very rewarding.
summary: Love it or leave it, it is what it is.

cons: The company has a very high pressure work atmosphere. Hours can be quite heavy during crunch time for every level and every LOB. Oracle is constantly changing and improving. Many reorgs take place but if you could put with changes, you can learn a lot.
advice: Take care of your workers. It's not all about your promotion.Motivating by fear only works for short term.
pros: Fantastic and smart network with the employees that work at Oracle. Good work and reward culture.Sales driven environment. Oracle is a great company to include on any resume. Very Structured. Great Brand Name Recognization, Great Training Program, Very optimistic young atmosphere
summary: Oracle is a great company to work for.

cons: Bureaucracy is rampant; decent level of redundancy across different departments leads to power battlesThere is a strong possibility of getting "Oraclized" - lack of ability to operate in high stress, 60-70 work week start-up environments
advice: Spend more time on defining group goals; establish clearly defined success criteria
pros: Career Opportunities are reasonable; ability to try out different BUs/countries before settling into the one you intend to grow
summary: Place to grow while maintaining work/life balance

cons: It's a BIG company and there is a good amount of process (documented and undocumented) as well as a fair amount of politics to navigate.
advice: Spend more time with customers in a meaningful way on a more regular basis.
pros: Financial stability and product leadership. The results are that in tough times like we're experiencing now, there is more opportunities and safety. For instance, the sales organization has built up a war chest that will prevent any RIF's for a substantial period of time. The products for the most part are leaders in their respective spaces and where there are gaps, the overall strategy to build out an entire integra… ted application and technology suite can trump the "best of breed" advantage.
summary: Oracle's a very steady ship to be on in some very turbulent economic times.

cons: Upper management is not employee focused enough. Average salary as compared to peers. Very Political.
advice: Listen to employees more. The ones at the client site know what they are talking about!
pros: The work life balance is extremely good at i-flex. Even though you get to work at top notch financial clients, the projects are manageable. You do get very close interaction with senior IT executives at the client site. These contacts are very useful if you ever plan to switch to the client.You will get very good opportunities to learn operations and processes followed in the financial industry.Good brand nam… e in the IT services field. Ths is specially true for the Flexcube product. Of course, now that it has been acquired by Oracle, the future remains to be seen.
summary: Great colleagues, average salary, below par management

cons: The size of Oracle prohibits a close knit community. It often takes several weeks, or longer, for important decisions to be made. I work for a company that was acquired by Oracle and the communnication has been deficient. There has been very little implementation of strategy, mostly talk of how great things will be. So far the numbers have not backed up the talk.
advice: Oracle management needs to communicate strategy at a detailed level, not just a Sr. management level.
pros: In the currnet econmic environment Oracle is one of the few safe havens of stablility. Wth the acquistion of numerous companies the portfolio of applications and products is becoming even more balanced. This leads to a tremendous amount of career opportunity across products. Employees have access to excellent training and the latest software to gain industry knowledge.Oracle continues to support acquired applicat… ions (PeopleSoft, JDE, Siebel etc) while at the same time developing Fusion applications for the next generation of software.
summary: It's a great company if you take the initiative to forge your own path

cons: Hard to feel fulfilled, feel like you are part of a giant machine. Not a great place for pure marketing career.
advice: Focus on growing your mid-senior managers into leadership positions
pros: Stable environment. Smart co-workers. Generally able to balance work & life. Good if you are in an engineering or sales or core product development role.
summary: Place to be if you are looking for stability

cons: For me, the main downside of working at Oracle was the lack of cohesiveness within the company. I felt very disconnected from other parts of the company. I was in Development, but felt detached from other product teams that supported our product. I feel that management in general is good, but my department was very secretive. Communication was not the best.
advice: Communicate better and share information with everyone.
pros: The best things about working for Oracle was gaining experience from a major software giant and having that experience listed on my resume. Oracle on your resume is very impressive. I also feel that the pay was competitive and the benefits were the best around. Great medical insurance and if you work at HQ--a fantastic campus.
summary: Great for resume, not the best internal communication

cons: The communication systems need to be more reliable. It takes a long time to send/receive email. Also, working in a large organization can make you feel like just another number instead of an individual.
advice: The communication system needs to be more reliable. Its a work in progress that is not there yet.
pros: It is a tremendous opportunity to learn and grow. The firm really backs learning, and there a many opportunities to increase one's education and to grow as an individual. The projects are challenging, and provide opportunities to learn as well. You will be challenged to use what you know.
summary: Oracle - a great place to learn and to grow.

cons: Oracle can be a really oppressive and depressing environment for sales people. Oracle has siloed sales teams and no team knows what any other team is doing. Consequently, customers are constantly complaining about the lack of internal communication at Oracle. It's not hard to find an irritated Oracle customer.Inside sales reps only have control of about 50% of their income. The rest of their income is dependent o… n their field reps to make up the rest of their income. You could be 150% of plan and could make less money than someone who was 50% of plan because their field sold a lot and yours didn't. This can make for some extremely disappointing paychecks.
advice: Make Oracle a less hostile environment for sales people and make it a funner place to work again.
pros: Oracle is a company where you can learn the ropes of selling to big companies. Oracle has a very rigorous sales process and has sales reps constantly working to better themselves so that they can sell more software. Oracle is a great place to learn the fast paced world of enterprise software.Oracle also has amazing benefits for both individuals and families. If you are looking for a place that has amazing benefit… s, this is the place.Also, if you're looking for a no travel sales job where you can make over $100K, this is a great place to work. Top inside sales reps can make upwards of $150K.
summary: Oracle, a great place to work as long as you're making them money.

cons: Requires self-motivation and self-direction to get things done.
advice: Continue growth, work to recognize top employees.
pros: Fast moving with opportunities to get involved in multiple different initiatives.
summary: Rewarding and Challenging Place to Work

cons: Tough go up the ladder within the oraganization.
advice: Needs more pragmatic approach.
pros: Opportunity to work from home. Great training and work experience.
summary: Great Place to work and learn. Not the best place for salary.

cons: Too large a companyToo much inertiaFocussed too much on the bottomlineVery sensitive to Wall StInsatiable urge to buy new companiesA confusing array of products available to offer to customerSort of glass ceiling for individual contributors seem to exist
advice: Recognize the fast movers before they move out
pros: Learning latest technologiesWorking with the best talentsIf you are working on Oracle technologies, this is the place to beLot to learn about working on and managing mega projectsLot of scope to learn about global business, impacts and system integrationEasy for everyone to recognize the company you work for - needs no introduction
summary: One that went away

cons: Large, slow-moving, some groups very political, career growth seems based more on who you know than completence.
advice: Stay focused on getting products out and not on politics or impractical goals.
pros: Good place to learn. Supportive of flexible time and telecommuting. Challenging technologies.
summary: Overall a good place for a working parent, but not a place where you get that fired up or passionate.

cons: Top management are strong but plenty of examples of poor management lower down the levels. Very political - lot of empire building mentality. Easy to burn out. Salaries not always competitive and bonus payment not reliable
advice: Clean house! Make sure you have the right middle management/organization leaders to motivate and keep good people working there.
pros: Exciting place to work - compared to some large companies it is a fast paced work environment. Cool technology. Prestigous brand. Diverse set of products and opportunity to move around within company if you are good at what you do. Great campus and pretty decent overall benefits package
summary: Challenging place to work sometimes but a great ride regardless!
role: Senior Director Product Management and Marketing

cons: suit and tie, top management takes care of themselves first. There seem to be a perception that you are only good if you have an MBA (particularly from the ivy leagues) and that MBAs can do anything, even if they have absolutely no aptitude, experience, or interest in the particular part of the job. E.g. QA, UI design, software design.
advice: look after your employees
pros: competitive, smart and very competitive bunch of people, on the whole people are easy to work with. Things got a little crazy at the last 12 months of it's existence, but otherwise management generally had good (if sometimes misguided) intentions.
summary: good bunch of people to work with

cons: Facilities management team are the most incompetent I have ever seen. Thankfully you don't have to deal with them often.
advice: Product synchronization madness must stop. There's too many dependencies to synchronize all the products.
pros: Flexibility and the ability to work independently. Great pay and benefits.
summary: Good Company To Work For.

cons: Oracle is not the most progressive when it comes to salary increases - especially when promotions are involved. One Senior Executive is rumored to have said in response to a complaint from a direct report about not being compensated adequately, "Your resume is your compensation!"
advice: Allow Middle Managers to use raises and bonuses as incentives for performance. Work to improve internal networking capacity and reduce bureaucracy.
pros: I feel supported at Oracle and like I'm given encouragement (if not incentive) for innovation in my field. The culture of entreprenurialism and innovation can be exciting and it's always nice to be able to say I work for Oracle - people may not know what we do, but that makes a good conversation starter!
summary: Looking for an opportunity to innovate? Great! But don't expect raises or incentives, unless you are in Sales!

cons: Pay raises and bonuses are not always often as I would like it.
advice: Please remember that the employees are the company's greatest asset. Encourage all the teams and different divisions to cooperate and work together.
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn and grow; internal training at Oracle is available and convienent.Medical, vision, and detail benefits are very good.
summary: Oracle provides lots of opportunity to learn and grow your professional skills.

cons: The salary may not be as competitive as similar firms. If you do not have much experience you will not be paid your fair market value as inexperience is something you pay a price for (although I believe that is the same at most large companies). Lack of work life balance can be an issue however not if you manage it well. Middle management can be very slow and opaque in communicating big changes but again that is the … same at most companies of a certain size and to an extent is the function of middle management.
advice: Stay the course
pros: Oracle has very good reputation and is considered to be one of the best in the industry. All the colleagues are nice and friendly to work with. It provides good on-the-job training to employees.
summary: Good place to work

cons: As a Oracle consultant, most projects are short terms (3-6 months max). You will be constantly changing projects which is very stressful sometimes. Company culture is different from most other companies. A very competitive place. In Oracle, you need to do more than your assigned projects. You were expected to help develop new business as well, which is a very important fact in your annual review and your promotion. N… ormally they like to give higher title to new hires to attract them. Once you join, it is very difficult to get promoted.
advice: A more transparent information sharing
pros: Oracle offered a very comprehensive benefit package and a good salary and bonus. A great place to learn new technology to improve yourself.
summary: Great place to work for but a different culture from most other companies.

cons: Incredible pressure to perform NO MATTER WHAT. They are very intolerant of outside circumstances and current market conditions. The numbers have to be met no matter what happens. No excuse is tolerated and that is because the expectations flow upwards. Each manager has heavy expectations on them and each one of their managers has even more on their shoulders.Also, Oracle will reduce staff regularly and withou… t any fanfare in the market place. They will whack chunks of the org chart with no notice. Only producing salespeople are safe.
advice: Think past the current quarter. Always mortgaging the future for the present.
pros: Great product line and prestige. Also, the vast majority of Oracle employees are very intelligent and very talented. It was great to work with a group of smart people.
summary: Oracle: Bring your A game.

cons: Upper-most management is not in touch with everyday work issues of underlings. No MBWA (Management by walking around). I've never had a conversation with my upper management VPs or Execs and I've been there over 14 years. The company is large and projects that involve several hundred employees are typically not well managed. Products are sometimes sloppy and not well designed, product goes out to customers with too m… any bugs/defects.
advice: Get out of your office and talk to the developers who work on the code day to day, ask questions, learn about internal problems, get out of your ivory tower.
pros: Flexible work hours, telecommuting, technology leader, very understanding about work/life balance, able to offer time off for emergencies, flex time.
summary: Oracle is successful despite it's lack of management skills.

cons: Working for a large company like Oracle, it's sometimes frustrating to be simply a small link is a very large machine. Bureaucracy makes it difficult if not impossible to bnreak out and try innovative approaches since there may be risk associated with these new things. There tends to be a mind set of, let's just tick the box and say we did it, instead of a culture of excellence where not only did we do something but … we did it very well. This acceptance of mediocrity is easy to hide in a large organization and stifles innovation and the ability to create gound breaking messaging.
advice: Senior management by and large is very supportive of the entire infa structure but is often focused on the long term stratgic planning and over arching goals for the company. While this visionary thinking is needed, it means that the level of day to day feedback is minimal and the only real commentary that is provided typically surrounds a situation where course correctio n is needed.
pros: Oracle is an industry leader and it has great name recognition so it easily opens doors.The management is very supporive of the Inside Sales function and that makes a better environment as a launchpoint for success. The benefits are very good which is a blessing in todday's environment. As part of the Utilities group marketing into a fairly recession proof sector, job stability seems to be pretty solid. Innovation ar… ound products and the creation of marketing collateral to support the sales efforts is quite high class and allows us to present ourselves as technology anf thought leaders. In all, a pretty good place to land.
summary: Oracle sets the Pace with Inside Sales

cons: Because of the size of the organization, it is easy for an employee to get lost and dehumanized. Even though continuing education is offered, it is almost impossible to get it approved. Salaries and wages are usually minimal to midline of what the current area market is, and once you have accepted a starting wage it increases a maximum of 3%, and often several years pass by with no raise (irregardless of performance.… ) Oracle only matches a small portion of the 401K and that match can exclusively be invested in Oracle stock, an exact quote from the benefits page, 50% of your first 6% in contributions, so Oracle is matching your first 6% at 3%, almost nothing.
advice: Stress teamwork and create an award system that encourages employee's efforts.
pros: Oracle is a global corporation offering some employment stability in a dark economic climate. The benefits package is good and offers reasonable options. Oracle encourages team oriented activity and growth. Continuing education is offered and encouraged.
summary: Oracle, Neither Good Nor Bad

cons: I would not recommend it as a place for a first job though. The training and people development is not as good as I have seen it. I used to be a consultant working for the big 5 and at those companies the training is top notch. I'm lucky that I got that training and development before I came to Oracle.
advice: Senior Management should place more emphasis on the yearly evaluation process and ensure it is a fair process of evaluating employees. Also the raises and bonuses need to be bigger or they need to be more fairly allocated to the people who deserve it.
pros: Oracle is a great place to settle down in. In general at least in my job, there is a lot of flexibility in the work schedule. This is mainly due to the fact that it is an international business and many of my colleagues are overseas. It doesn't make sense to work 9-5 when you have either early morning calls or late night calls with overseas or people on the other coast.
summary: Offers opportunity for a work life balance, but don't expect much influence on salary

cons: There is an unhealthy influence from management to do whatever is neccesary to "get the job done" which prevents a clear distinction between work and personal time. This wouldn't be such a problem if they were more flexible with salespeople working from home. The pressure on the sales staff is average most of the time, however, pressure increases exponentially during the end of fiscal quarters or due to turn-over rel… ated issues.
advice: My main advice to management at Oracle would be to coordinate communications better so that employees are not bombarded constantly with emails, conference calls, and ad hoc meetings to discuss the same issue or topic which wastes way too much time in today's economy. It would also be helpful if senior management would fully outline the expected hallmarks for career advancement and then stick to them....
pros: There are plenty of oppritunities to make money at Oracle and those who are sucessful are well rewarded. There are great benefits like in-office gym, frequent catered meals, and extensive training, all free of charge.
summary: You're only as good as your last fiscal quarter
